THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Sherrie Jean Floyd, Respondent,
        v.
        Richard Morgan, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Rolly W. Jacobs, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  4289
  Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed August 23,
  2007

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        J. Mark Taylor and Katherine Carruth Link, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Richard Giles Whiting and Spencer Andrew Syrett, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Richard Morgan (Father) appeals from a
  family court order granting Sherrie Jean Floydâ€™s (Mother) request for a child
  support reduction.Â  Father further argues the family court erred in modifying a
  contractual term of the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement, and in denying his request
  for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In August 2000, the family court granted Father a
  divorce from Mother on the ground of adultery.Â  Pursuant to an agreement of the
  parties, the court granted sole custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor children to Father,
  and visitation in excess of 109 overnights per year to Mother.Â  Mother agreed
  to pay child support in the amount of $920 per month.Â  The amount of child
  support was calculated by the parties pursuant to Worksheet A of the South
  Carolina Child Support Guidelines (the guidelines).Â  Mother also agreed to pay
  Father $17,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  All of these provisions were part
  of a negotiated settlement agreement approved by the family court and
  incorporated into the divorce decree.Â  
In May 2004, Mother sought sole custody of
  the children or, alternatively, a shared or joint custody arrangement.Â  Mother
  also sought modification of her child support.Â  Upon request of both Father and
  Mother, the court appointed a guardian ad litem for the children.Â  Father and
  Mother agreed that because Fatherâ€™s income had increased and Motherâ€™s income had
  decreased, they would temporarily reduce Motherâ€™s child support payment from
  $920 to $808 per month while the action was pending. Â This reduction was
  approved by the court. Â Again in 2006, Father and Mother agreed to modify their
  original agreement as to visitation, but not materially modifying the number of
  overnight visits the mother had with the children.
However, the parties did not reach an agreement as to
  two issues: (1) Motherâ€™s request to permanently modify child support, and (2)
  both Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s requests for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The parties
  disputed whether child support should be calculated in accordance with Worksheet
  A (for sole custody) or Worksheet C (for shared custody) of the guidelines.[2]
In June 2006, the court granted Motherâ€™s
  request to modify the provisions of the divorce decree regarding child support,
  finding the changes in the partiesâ€™ incomes and the elimination of child care
  expenses in the amount of $544.00 per month constituted a change of
  circumstances. Â The court further held that it would exercise its discretion
  and calculate Motherâ€™s new child support obligation utilizing Worksheet C of
  the guidelines, instead of Worksheet A.Â  Utilizing the guidelines, the court
  reduced Motherâ€™s child support obligation to $152 per month.Â  The court
  additionally ordered that each party be responsible for his or her own
  attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
In
  appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with our
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v.
    Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the
  family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d
  610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522
  S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Modification of Child Support
Father contends the family court erred in granting
  Motherâ€™s request for a
  reduction in child support when there was no evidence to support the courtâ€™s
  finding of a change in circumstances with respect to the level of Motherâ€™s
  overnight visitation.Â  We disagree.
The family court may always modify child support upon
  a proper showing of a change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting
  parentâ€™s financial ability.Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 26, 624
  S.E.2d 643, 647-48 (2006) (citing Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 351,
  306 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1983)).Â  The party seeking the modification has the burden
  to show changed circumstances.Â  Id. at 26, 624 S.E.2d at 648.Â  This
  burden is increased where the child support award is based on a settlement
  agreement.Â  Id.Â  Moreover, changes within the contemplation of the
  parties at the time of the initial decree are not sufficient bases for the
  modification of a child support award.Â  Id.
In the present case, the family court placed great
  emphasis on the substantial changes in the partiesâ€™ incomes.Â  In its June 14,
  2006 order, the court noted that at the time of the divorce in 2000, Father
  earned $4000 per month in income, while Mother earned $4067.Â  By the time of
  the initial hearing in 2004, Fatherâ€™s monthly income increased 29% to $5150,
  while Motherâ€™s income only increased 18% to $4800.Â  By 2005, Fatherâ€™s income
  increased again to $5421, while Motherâ€™s income decreased to $4785.Â  Then, at
  the time of the final hearing in 2006, Fatherâ€™s income increased to $5700,
  while Motherâ€™s income increased back to $4800.Â  The court concluded that in
  2006, Fatherâ€™s income increased 43% from 2000, while Motherâ€™s income increased
  only 18% between 2000 and 2006.Â  Additionally, the court noted that child care
  expenses, which were apparently paid by Father, no longer existed and that the medical
  expenses had not changed substantially since the 2000 decree.
We agree with the family court that the above
  mentioned changes were significant enough to support a finding of a substantial
  or material change of circumstances warranting a modification of child support.
  Â See Rogers v. Rogers, 343 S.C. 329, 540 S.E. 2d 840 (2001) (holding
  Fatherâ€™s 21% increase in income, as compared to Motherâ€™s 8% increase in income,
  together with increased child care expenses warranted increase in child
  support).
II.Â  Calculation of Amount of Child Support
Father contends the family court erred in modifying a
  contractual term of the partiesâ€™ negotiated settlement agreement, from the use
  of Worksheet A to Worksheet C to govern Motherâ€™s child support obligation,
  inasmuch as theÂ  Motherâ€™s overnight visitation did not materially change. Â We
  disagree.
 Whether
  or not the family court had discretion upon a finding of change of
  circumstances to change the method of calculating child support, utilizing a
  different guidelines worksheet when there was no material change in the number
  of overnight visits, is a novel issue in South Carolina. Â As previously stated,
  ordinarily, a party seeking to modify an existing child support obligation has
  the burden of establishing changed circumstances.Â  Upchurch, 367 S.C. at
  26, 624 S.E.2d at 648.Â  To warrant a change in child support, the change of
  circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  Townsend v. Townsend,
  356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
South
  Carolina Code Annotated section 20-7-852(A) (Supp. 2006) states that â€œ[i]n any
  proceeding for the award of child support, there is a rebuttable presumption
  that the amount of the award which would result from the application of the
  guidelines required under section 43-5-580(b) is the correct amount of child
  support to be awarded.â€ Â A different amount may be awarded only â€œupon a showing
  that application of the guidelines in a particular case would be unjust or
  inappropriate.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, â€œ[w]hen the court orders a child support
  award that varies significantly from the amount resulting from the application
  of the guidelines, the court shall make specific, written findings of those
  facts upon which it bases its conclusion supporting that award.â€ Â Id.Â  Section 20-7-852(C) (Supp. 2006) states a court â€œshallâ€ consider certain
  factors which â€œ. . . may be used in determining whether a change of
  circumstances has occurred which would require a modification of an existing
  order.â€ Â Among other reasons, section 20-7-852(C)(11) states the court may
  consider â€œsubstantial disparity of incomes in which the noncustodial parentâ€™s
  income is significantly less than the custodial parentâ€™s income, thus making it
  financially impractical to pay what the guidelines indicate the noncustodial
  parent should pay.â€
Regulation
  114-4720 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides the court can determine
  the total child support obligation by adding the basic child support as
  provided in the guidelines to health insurance premiums and child care costs. Â Thereafter,
  â€œthe total child support obligation is divided between the parents in
  proportion to their incomes.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(15)(a) (Supp.
  2006). Â There is no contention by the parties that the trial court did not
  properly compute each parentâ€™s child support obligation based upon a literal
  application of the guidelines.
Further,
  regulation 114-4730(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides that â€œ[w]hen
  both parents are deemed fit, and other relevant logistical circumstances apply,
  shared custody should be encouraged . . . .â€ Â The regulation states further
  that shared custody adjustments are advisory, not mandatory. Â Id.Â 
  Additionally, if each parent has court-ordered visitation with the children
  overnight for more than 109 nights each year and both parents contribute to the
  expenses of the children in addition to the payment of child support, the court
  may make a â€œshared custody adjustment,â€ which â€œshall be calculated using
  Worksheet C.â€Â  Id.Â  The regulation goes on to explain that â€œif the 109
  overnights threshold is reached for shared physical custody, this adjustment
  may be applied even if one parent has sole legal custody.â€Â  Id.
In 2000, at the
  time Father and Mother entered into the agreement in question, Motherâ€™s
  visitations were approximately 147 overnights visits per year, which was
  clearly in excess of the 109 overnight visits required to put into play the
  shared parenting provisions of the guidelines.Â  Despite the number of overnight
  visits granted, Mother agreed to pay Father $920 per month in child support
  based upon figures set forth in an attached â€œChild Support Obligation:
  Worksheet A.â€Â  Although Motherâ€™s attorney argued to the trial court in
  this case that the Mother knew nothing about the various worksheets when she
  signed the 2000 agreement, the agreement declares both parties entered into the
  agreement freely, not under duress or undue influence, and that they actively
  took part in the negotiations. Â Additionally, the family court found the
  agreement to be fair, equitable and reasonable, and approved the agreement as
  incorporated and merged into the divorce decree.Â  Nevertheless, the 2000 decree
  does not explain why there was a deviation from the amount that should have
  presumably been awarded by application of the guidelines.Â  Nor, did the decree
  or agreement in any way bind the parties to the use of worksheet A in future
  child support calculations based on a change of circumstances. 
In
  the groundbreaking 1983 case of Moseley v. Mosier, supra, our
  supreme court stated in rather specific terms that â€œfamily courts have
  continuing jurisdiction to do whatever is in the best interest of the child
  regardless of what the separation agreement specified.â€Â  Moseley, 279
  S.C. at 351, 306 S.E.2d at 626.Â  Moreover, it is clear that a merged child
  support agreement loses its contractual character after it is judicially decreed
  as mandated by Moseley. Â Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 214, 603
  S.E.2d 598, 601-03 (Ct. App. 2004).
While
  no South Carolina case touches upon the scenario of this case, the North Carolina case of Beamer v. Beamer, 610 S.E.2d 220 (N.C. Ct. App. 2005),
  reflects on how our sister state views the matter. Â In Beamer, the court
  reversed the trial court deviation from the guidelines for lack of specific
  findings of fact to support the â€œ(1) the reasonable needs of the children and
  (2) the basis for the amount of child support ultimately awarded.â€ Â Id. at 221.Â  Procedurally, the court stated, however, that â€œ[o]nce a substantial
  change in circumstances has been shown by the party seeking modification, the
  trial court then â€˜proceeds to follow the Guidelines and to compute the
  appropriate amount of child support.â€™ â€ Â Id. at 222 (citing Davis v.
    Risley, 411 S.E.2d 171, 173 (N.C. Ct. App. 1991)).
The
  parties are in agreement that Mother has custody of the children approximately
  147 overnights per year or roughly 40% of the time. Â The idea behind the
  adjustments for shared custody is that the party having custody of the children
  during a certain time period will take care of most of the childrenâ€™s needs
  during the time he/she has custody. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Regs.
  114-4730(A).Â  As we read the statute and regulation, they presume that the
  appropriate amount of support in a shared parenting arrangement is the amount
  resulting from an application of the guidelines. Â Since neither party claims
  the trial judge should have deviated from the guidelines due to any of the
  statutory reasons set forth in section 20-7-852(C),[3] or that the modification of Motherâ€™s support obligation will somehow adversely
  affect the welfare of the children, we think it was simply a mathematical
  calculation on the part of the trial court to establish support based on the
  guidelines. Â Therefore, we hold the trial court had discretion to apply the guidelines
  then in effect upon a showing of a substantial change of circumstances.
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Father contends the family court erred in denying him
  attorneyâ€™s fees when he was the prevailing party with respect to the issues
  raised in this action.Â  We disagree.
Attorneyâ€™s
  fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the family court.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2005); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C.
  515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004). The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within
  the discretion of the court.Â  Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 31, 590
  S.E.2d 495, 502 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The family courtâ€™s decision regarding
  attorneyâ€™s fees will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Green
    v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 353, 465 S.E.2d 130, 134 (Ct. App. 1995).
In
  deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider:
  (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees; (2) the beneficial results
  obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial condition of each party; and
  (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Upchurch,
  367 S.C. at 28, 624 S.E.2d at 648-49; Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C.
  255, 269, 621 S.E.2d 389, 396 (Ct. App. 2005).
Here,
  Mother brought this action for a change in custody.Â  Although the parties
  settled the custody aspect of the case, we have concluded the family court did
  not err in reducing Motherâ€™s child support.Â  We thus hold that neither party
  prevailed.Â  In any event, the family court ordered that each party be
  responsible for his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. We therefore find
  that the family court did not err in denying Father attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the family court did
  not err by granting Motherâ€™s request for a reduction in child support.Â  We also
  find the family court did not err by modifying a contractual term of the
  partiesâ€™ negotiated settlement agreement, from the use of Worksheet A to Worksheet
  C of the child support guidelines, to govern Motherâ€™s child support obligation.
  Â Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, J., concurs.
SHORT, J.,
  dissents in part and concurs in part in a separate opinion.
SHORT, J. (dissenting in part and concurring in part):Â  I would reverse the family courtâ€™s
  recalculation of child support utilizing Worksheet C in place of the originally
  agreed upon Worksheet A of the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (the
  Guidelines), and for that reason, I respectfully dissent.Â  I adopt the
  majorityâ€™s facts and standard of review, but I disagree with the analysis and
  would find as follows.
The majority utilizes Upchurch v. Upchurch for
  the proposition that the family court may always modify child support upon a
  proper showing of change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s
  financial ability.Â  367 S.C. 16, 26, 624 S.E.2d 643, 647-48 (2006).Â  While I
  agree with the majority that due to significant changes in the partiesâ€™ income,
  a modification of the child support amount was appropriate, I find this
  modification should have been calculated under Worksheet A of the
  Guidelines.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In an August 30, 2000 order (the 2000 order), the
  family court fully approved, incorporated and merged the partiesâ€™ custody,
  support and property settlement agreement into its order.Â  This agreement
  called for Mother to pay â€œFather the amount of $920.00 per month in child
  support based upon figures set forth in the attached Child Support Obligation
  Worksheet A.â€Â Â  The family court found that the parties had negotiated and
  entered into the agreement with â€œthe benefit of advice and counselâ€ and that
  they â€œfully comprehended its terms and conditions.â€Â  Further, the court found
  each party entered into a â€œfair, equitable, and reasonableâ€ agreement â€œfreely,
  knowingly, voluntarily, and without threats or coercion.â€Â  
I first note that this 2000 order of the family court was
  never appealed.Â  Therefore, it has become the law of the case, and any review
  of the propriety of utilizing Worksheet A, as noted in the partiesâ€™ agreement
  and consequently the courtâ€™s order, would be contrary to our rules of
  preservation.[4]Â 
  The majority correctly notes regulation 114-4730(A) of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2006) provides a family court with discretion to apply a â€œshared
  custody adjustmentâ€ which provides for the utilization of Worksheet C to
  calculate child support for parents who have court ordered visitation with a
  child for more than 109 overnights each year.Â  However, to review the family
  courtâ€™s 2000 order for an abuse of discretion error at this juncture would be
  inappropriate.Â  The proper query to be addressed in this matter is whether the
  necessary change of circumstances has occurred to modify the original order by
  calculating child support under Worksheet C instead of Worksheet A.Â 
  Nonetheless, even were we to review the propriety of utilizing Worksheet A in
  the 2000 order, I believe this issue fails on its merits.Â  The majority notes
  that the family court failed to provide specific findings of fact to explain
  why it deviated from the Guidelines in calculating the child support owed.Â 
  While I agree that were the court to deviate from the Guidelines in its own
  discretion it would have to provide specific findings to justify this action,
  in this matter, the parties agreed to utilize Worksheet A.Â  The parties
  are free to agree on child support which is greater than that as required by
  law.Â  See Ratchford v. Ratchford, 295 S.C. 297, 299, 368 S.E.2d
  214, 215 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œA parent can contractually obligate himself beyond
  the support requirements imposed by law.â€).Â  Where the parties agree to a
  greater amount of support than required by law, I fail to discern why the
  family court should be required to make specific findings of fact to justify
  such deviation from the Guidelines.[5]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Regardless of the propriety of the family courtâ€™s
  application of Worksheet A to calculate child support under the 2000 order, as
  noted above, the family court retains jurisdiction to modify child support upon
  a proper showing of change in either the childâ€™s needs or the supporting
  parentâ€™s financial ability.Â  â€œWhere there is an agreement regarding child
  support, however, the family court should not decide support issues as if there
  is no agreement.â€Â  Ratchford, 295 S.C. at 299, 368 S.E.2d at 215.Â  The
  parties agreed to calculate the support obligation under Worksheet A, and as
  reflected in the 2000 order, this calculation based on the parties then
  existing income, resulted in an amount of $920.00.Â  While the dollar amount was
  determined through a calculation based on the partiesâ€™ then existing incomes
  and not based on the partiesâ€™ specific assent, the decision to utilize
  Worksheet A was agreed upon by the parties.Â  Consequently, I believe that while
  the dollar amount is modifiable based on changes in the income of the parties,
  I do not find the use of Worksheet A to be modifiable based solely on changes
  in the parties income.[6]Â 
  A change in worksheets should be predicated on a change in the visitation such
  that Mother would increase her overnights from an amount less than 109 nights
  to an amount in excess of 109 nights thereby providing the court with discretion
  to apply the shared custody adjustment as noted in regulation 114-4730(A) of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  However, it is undisputed that Mother
  was afforded visitation in excess of 109 overnights in the 2000 order.Â 
  Consequently, she agreed to calculate her support obligation under Worksheet A
  while already having visitation in excess of 109 overnights per year.Â  Mother
  â€œfreely, knowingly, voluntarily, and without threats or coercionâ€ agreed to
  forego the possibility of a shared custody adjustment.Â  Therefore, we have no
  substantial change in the visitation, and Mother is not entitled to a
  modification of her previously agreed to usage of Worksheet A.Â  
Further,
  the majority cites Upchurch for the notion that â€œchanges within the
  contemplation of the parties at the time of the initial decree are not
  sufficient bases for the modification of a child support award.â€Â  367 S.C. at
  26, 624 S.E.2d at 648.Â  I agree and can discern no manner in which one could
  argue Mother, having been afforded over 109 overnights per year by the 2000
  order and thereby potentially being entitled to a shared custody adjustment,
  did not have the use of a particular worksheet within her contemplation when
  she agreed to utilize Worksheet A.Â  
For
  these reasons, I would reverse the family courtâ€™s usage of Worksheet C and
  remand the issue of child support for calculation of a proper support
  obligation under the agreed upon Worksheet A.Â  As to the other issues noted in
  this appeal, I concur with the majority.Â Â Â 
  

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Neither party testified at the hearing before the
  trial court. Â Instead, both partiesâ€™ attorneys made statements to the court,
  which were essentially undisputed by opposing counsel. Â The record on appeal
  contains the affidavit of Fatherâ€™s counsel requesting attorney fees, but we are
  uninformed what other documents, if any, were before the trial court. Â The
  trial courtâ€™s order indicates the Mother submitted some documentation as to
  additional sums she spent on the children over and above the support she paid
  the Father.
[3] We recognize that arguably Father contends the partiesâ€™
  agreement from 2000 is a sufficient basis to not apply the worksheet component
  of the statute, but we read section 20-7-852(C)(13) to apply in the present
  situation to the 2000 support order only, inasmuch as the parties reached no
  agreement as to child support in 2006.
[4] We are mindful that the appellate courts of this
  state have disregarded rules of error preservation where the best interests of
  a child were concerned.Â  See Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 536
  S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000).Â  However, as the majority notes, the changing of
  worksheets in this matter does not effect the interests of the children;Â  â€œit
  was simply a mathematical calculation on the part of the trial court to
  establish support based on the guidelines.â€Â  
[5] The North Carolina Court of Appeals case (Beamer
  v. Beamer, 610 S.E.2d 220 (2005)), utilized by the majority to support its point
  that deviation from the Guidelines must be supported by specific findings of
  fact, is distinguishable from the matter at hand.Â  In the Beamer case,
  there was no agreement by the parties as to which worksheet to apply, and the
  court sua sponte determined it should calculate support in a
  manner not consistent with the North Carolina Guidelines.Â Â Â  
[6] I again note the majorityâ€™s use of Beamer to
  establish that â€œonce a substantial change in circumstances has been shown by
  the party seeking modification, the trial court then â€˜proceeds to follow the
  Guidelines and to compute the appropriate amount of child support.â€™â€Â  This
  intimates that once a substantial change has been found, the court is free to
  change even the worksheet to be used.Â  This may hold true in cases such as Beamer where there is no prior agreement of the parties as to which worksheet to use.Â 
  However, in light of the precedent handed down in Ratchford dictating
  that where there is an agreement, the court should not decide support issues as
  if there is no agreement, I find Beamer to be unpersuasive under the
  facts of this case.

title: Maxwell v. Lette
description: In this domestic action, Husband appeals from the family court's order dismissing his action to terminate alimony awarded to Wife pursuant to a settlement agreement in the parties' prior separate maintenance and support action.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Dallas S. Maxwell, Jr., Appellant,
				v.
				Lori L. Maxwell, now known as Lori Denise Lette, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â Henry T. Woods, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4290
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed August 24, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
				Charles D. Lee, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.:Â  Dallas S. Maxwell (Husband) appeals from the family court's order dismissing his action to terminate the alimony that Lori Maxwell[1] (Wife) was awarded pursuant to a settlement agreement in the parties' prior action for separate maintenance and support.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Wife and Husband separated in April 2002, and Wife filed an action for separate maintenance and support in May 2002.Â  Although Wife was the only party represented by counsel, the parties entered into a settlement agreement that was adopted by the family court by final order on June 14, 2002.Â  The agreement granted Wife custody of the parties' three minor children with liberal visitation to Husband.Â  As part of the agreement, Wife was granted unallocated family support of $2,600 per month for ten years and, upon the emancipation of the three minor children, alimony in an amount equal to the unallocated support.Â  The alimony was to be reduced to $1,000 per month in January 2013.Â  The settlement agreement provided that alimony was "non-modifiable and shall continue until the death of the Husband."Â  The agreement further provided that: Â (1) if the agreement was adopted by the family court, it would be the final determination of all the financial and marital rights of the parties such that there was no need for the issues to be relitigated in a subsequent divorce action; and (2) the provisions of the agreement could not be modified by the parties or the family court except by mutual written consent of both parties in a formal agreement adopted by the family court.Â  Neither party appealed from the order adopting the settlement agreement.Â 
 
Sometime after the final order issued by the family court adopting the settlement agreement, Husband learned that Wife committed adultery prior to the adoption of the agreement.Â  On May 23, 2003, Husband filed an action for divorce based upon adultery.Â  In the complaint, Husband also requested termination of alimony based upon Wife's pre-agreement adultery.Â  After a bifurcated trial, the family court first granted the parties a divorce based upon the grounds of the separation of the parties without cohabitation for greater than one year.Â  In a separate order, the court considered whether Husband was barred from seeking termination of alimony.Â  The court dismissed Husband's claim to terminate alimony with prejudice, finding:Â  (1) Husband failed to raise or plead the avoidance or affirmative defense of adultery to Wife's claim for alimony in the separation agreement, and thus, he was barred from raising it in a subsequent action; (2) Husband's claims were barred by res judicata and collateral estoppel; and (3) the separation agreement provided that alimony was non-modifiable, and thus, the family court could not terminate alimony.Â  Husband's motion for reconsideration was denied, and he appeals.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family court's findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  "Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony."Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Dorchester County Dep't of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family court's findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of his burden to convince this court that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in dismissing his action to terminate alimony because adultery is listed as an absolute bar to alimony pursuant to statute.Â  We disagree.
Whether to award alimony is a decision within the sound discretion of the family court judge and the decision will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The South Carolina Code provides for an award of alimony in amounts for such terms as the family court considers appropriate and just, considering the parties' circumstances, and the circumstances of the case.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A) (Supp. 2006).Â  The statute further provides:

	No alimony may be awarded a spouse who commits adultery before the earliest of these two events:Â  (1) the formal signing of a written property or marital settlement agreement or (2) entry of a permanent order approving a property or marital settlement agreement between the parties.

Id.Â  The statutory bar on alimony due to adultery, however, is not absolute.Â  See RGM v. DEM, 306 S.C. 145, 150, 410 S.E.2d 564, 567 (1991) (noting that while condonation is a defense to the statutory bar of alimony due to adultery, recrimination is not); Doe v. Doe, 286 S.C. 507, 512, 334 S.E.2d 829, 832 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding that husband could not avail himself of the statute barring alimony to an adulterous spouse where husband condoned wife's adultery, and thus wife was still eligible for alimony). 
 
Further, the parties may enter a settlement agreement making the payment of alimony non-modifiable and not subject to subsequent modification by the family court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(G) (Supp. 2006) (stating that the family court may review and approve all agreements bearing on support issues, including alimony, and that the parties "may agree in writing if properly approved by the court to make the payment of alimony as set forth in items (1) through (6) of subsection (B) nonmodifiable and not subject to subsequent modification by the court").[2]Â  "While the family court normally has the authority to modify alimony, once an alimony agreement that specifically disallows modification is approved by the court and merged into a judicial order, it is binding on the parties and the court and is not subject to modification."Â  Degenhart, 360 S.C. at 500-01, 602 S.E.2d at 98.Â  The family court "must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms regardless of its wisdom or folly, apparent unreasonableness, or the parties' failure to guard their rights carefully."Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 340, 491 S.E.2d 583, 589 (Ct. App. 1997). 
 
In the present case, the parties' agreement specifically provided that it was not modifiable by the parties or by the family court unless both parties agreed in writing to modify it by a formal procedure in the family court.Â  Because the terms of the agreement provide that it is non-modifiable, it is irrelevant that Wife committed adultery prior to signing the separation agreement and that the statute bars alimony to an adulterous spouse.Â  The agreement "overrides" the statutory bar to alimony.Â  Degenhart, 360 S.C. at 500-01, 602 S.E.2d at 98.Â  Thus, we find no error in the family court's decision to dismiss the action to terminate alimony.[3] 
 
CONCLUSION
Because the underlying settlement agreement between the parties provided that it was non-modifiable, we find the family court did not err in dismissing Husband's action to terminate the alimony award in the agreement.Â  Accordingly, the family court's order is
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Wife now goes by the name "Lori Lette."Â 
 
[2]Â  We note that this subsection was not cited by the family court judge in reaching his decision.Â  However, this section was in existence at the time the underlying action for termination of alimony was filed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(G) (Supp. 2002).Â  
 
[3]Â  Because we affirm the family court on this issue, we decline to address Husband's remaining grounds on appeal.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding that the court need not rule on remaining issues when the disposition of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).Â

title: Robbins v. Walgreens
description: In this workers' compensation case, Robbins appeals from the denial of his claim for additional compensation based on a change of conditions.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Bryan Patrick Robbins, Appellant,
				v.
				Walgreens and Broadspire Services, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4291
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed August 24, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Stephen B. Samuels, of Sumter, for Appellant.
				Lana H. Sims, Jr., of Columbia, Mary Sowell League, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this workers' compensation case, Bryan Robbins appeals from the circuit court's order affirming the Appellate Panel of the Workers' Compensation Commission's denial of his claim for additional compensation based on a change of condition, arguing:Â  (1) he sustained a change of condition within the meaning of the act; and (2) he is entitled to additional medical benefits, including surgery, even if he did not sustain a change of condition because the treatment would tend to lessen his period of disability.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Robbins was the assistant manager at a Walgreens pharmacy in Sumter.Â  On April 13, 2003, he injured his lower back while stacking cases of two-liter sodas on a cart.Â  He reported the injury to his employer, filed a workers' compensation claim, and received compensation for his injury.Â  Robbins was placed on disability for two weeks and then allowed to return to work on light duty with weight restrictions.Â  Robbins was prescribed physical therapy, anti-inflammatory medication, and muscle relaxers.Â  His treating physician, orthopedic surgeon Dr. Rakesch Chokshi, diagnosed Robbins with degenerative disc disease at levels L1-2 and L2-3, with foraminal compression causing lumbar spine radiculopathy, and lumbar stenosis.Â  Dr. Chokshi released Robbins at maximum medical improvement with no work restrictions on September 24, 2003, with a 10% permanent impairment rating.Â  Robbins returned to work with some residual symptoms.Â  Although Robbins claimed his back pain slowly worsened after returning to work, Robbins settled his workers' compensation claim with Walgreens on March 12, 2004.Â  Robbins was terminated from his employment with Walgreens for unspecified reasons on April 12, 2004.Â 
 
April 16, 2004, Robbins went to his family physician complaining of back pain that never abated from the prior accident at work.Â  He was diagnosed with degenerative disc disease with radiculopathy.Â  Robbins returned to Dr. Chokshi, who diagnosed him with decreased lumbar motion secondary to facet arthropathy and degenerative changes and recommended further treatment.Â  Dr. Chokshi recommended that Robbins not work. Â On May 11, 2004, Robbins filed a Form 50 request for a hearing based on a change in condition to his back and leg and requesting further treatment.Â  Robbins sought treatment with Dr. Jefferey Wingate, who also diagnosed Robbins with disc degeneration at L1-2 and L2-3 with loss of disc height and signal.Â  Robbins, who had begun to work for Walden Books part-time and began taking night classes, told Dr. Wingate that his back is "shot" after working.Â  Dr. Wingate recommended further treatment, including discography, epidural injections, and a lumbar fusion.Â Â 
 
At the hearing, Robbins testified that his back pain was "much worse" than it was at the time he settled his original claim.Â  He also stated that his back pain was not resolved before he settled his claim, but he was afraid to inform his employer or request additional treatment for fear of being terminated.Â  Although he admitted that his current employment with Walden Books exhausted him, he denied that it exacerbated his condition.Â Â

 STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Appellate Panel of the Workers' Compensation Commission. Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981). Â "In workers' compensation cases, the [Appellate Panel] is the ultimate fact finder." Â Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The Appellate Panel is specifically reserved the task of assessing the credibility of the witnesses and the weight to be accorded evidence. Â Id. 
 
Thus, this court will not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Therrell v. Jerry's Inc., 370 S.C. 22, 25, 633 S.E.2d 893, 894 (2006).Â  "[T]his Court may reverse or modify the [Panel's] decision if Petitioner has suffered the appropriate degree of prejudice and the commission's decision is effected by an error of law or is â€˜clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.'" Â Id. at 25, 633 S.E.2d at 894-95 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(2005)).Â  "It is not within our province to reverse findings of the [Appellate Panel] which are supported by substantial evidence." Â Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  "Substantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached."Â  Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1996).Â  The mere possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agency's finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Grant v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 353, 461 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1995).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Change of condition
Robbins argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panel because:Â  (1) the undisputed evidence was that Dr. Chokshi took Robbins out of work due to his back pain in April 2004, entitling him to additional compensation; (2) the Appellate Panel erred in requiring a "significant" change in condition; and (3) the Panel's findings were not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
A claimant may seek to reopen an award under the Workers' Compensation Act if there has been a change in condition.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-90 (1985) (providing that, upon the motion of any party based upon a change of condition, any award may be reviewed and thereafter diminished or increased).Â  "The purpose of this section is to enable the [Appellate Panel] to change the amount of compensation, including increasing compensation when circumstances indicate a change of condition for the worse." Â Clark v. Aiken County Gov't, 366 S.C. 102, 108, 620 S.E.2d 99, 102 (Ct. App. 2005). Â "A change in condition occurs when the claimant experiences a change in physical condition as a result of her original injury, occurring after the first award."Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW # 10420, 353 S.C. 100, 109, 576 S.E.2d 191, 196 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, the issue before the Appellate Panel is "sharply restricted to the question of extent of improvement or worsening of the injury on which the original award was based."Â  Id. 
 
We believe there was substantial evidence to support the denial of Robbins' claim of a change in condition.Â  The MRI taken before Robbins' original claim for compensation showed he had degenerative disc disease at levels L1-2 and L2-3, with foraminal compression causing lumbar spine radiculopathy and lumbar stenosis.Â  The MRI taken by Dr. Wingate after the settlement of Robbins' original claim showed that Robbins suffered from disc degeneration at L1-2 and L2-3 with loss of disc height and signal.Â  Thus, the evidence both before and after the settlement of his claim showed the same condition.Â  Neither Dr. Chokshi nor Dr. Wingate opined that Robbins' condition had worsened; they only noted that his pain was continuing.Â  Robbins testified at the hearing before the single commissioner that his pain never abated after his injury, he just failed to inform Walgreens prior to the settlement for fear of being terminated.Â  It is irrelevant that Dr. Chokshi took Robbins out of work in April 2004 because the only evidence in the record regarding the state of Robbins' condition was that it was similar both before and after the settlement.Â  Further, although the single commissioner's order stated that Robbins failed to prove he sustained a "significant change" in his condition, the commissioner used the correct standard in reviewing the evidence and found it did not support a finding that he suffered a "physical change of condition for the worse."Â  Accordingly, there was substantial evidence in the record to support the finding that Robbins failed to prove a change or worsening of his condition.Â 
 
II. Additional medical treatment
Robbins argues the circuit court erred in affirming the denial of his request for additional medical treatment because it would have lessened his period of disability.Â  We disagree.
We agree with the circuit court that Robbins failed to preserve this matter for appeal.Â  Although he requested "additional medical examination and treatment" due to a change of condition in his post-settlement Form 50, Robbins did not argue before the single commissioner that he was entitled to continuing medical treatment after the date he reached MMI in order to lessen his period of disability.Â  The single commissioner only ruled on Robbins' change of condition claim and did not specifically rule on the alternate claim that Robbins was entitled to continuing medical treatment in order to lessen his period of disability.Â  Although Robbins raised the issue of his entitlement to continuing medical treatment in order to lessen his period of disability in his appeal to the Appellate Panel, Robbins only argued he was entitled to compensation for a change in condition.Â  Because the matter was not argued before the single commissioner or the Appellate Panel, Robbins waived the matter.Â  It is not appropriate for this court to review the issue for the first time on appeal.Â  City of Columbia v. Ervin, 330 S.C. 516, 519-20, 500 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1998) (holding than an issue not argued to an intermediate appellate court is not preserved for review in the supreme court or the court of appeals). 
 
CONCLUSION
There was substantial evidence in the record to support the single commissioner's and the Appellate Court's findings that Robbins failed to prove a change in condition.Â  Further, because Robbins failed to argue that he was entitled to continuing medical treatment after MMI in order to lessen his period of disability, this issue is not preserved.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court's order affirming the Appellate Panel is
AFFIRMED.
